body: Should this be merged before #1466?

@markusweimer correct. I just pushed the changes requested by @motus 

After this gets rolled in, I will integrate it with #1466
@mandyshieh This PR needs rebase to resolve conflicts.
@mandyshieh This PR needs rebase to resolve conflicts.
I created this - https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-2038
@motus @markusweimer FYI: finished merging with #1467. Let me know if you guys think this PR is ready to go. I'd like to start syncing with another branch containing the C# side of the bridge.

@tcondie I will take another pass thorough the code now, and post my approval here.

@markusweimer, I think the sheer size of the change requires a second pair of eyeballs to review this PR before I merge it. WDYT?
@motus I did a surface scan for maintainability issues. Assuming they are addressed, I am fine with merging this.
Thanks @markusweimer for looking at it. I am running the tests now and doing a final scan over the code, and will merge it soon afterwards.
@singlis @mandyshieh Sure! I am looking at it now.

@markusweimer @motus @singlis @rogancarr This PR is for new REEF.Net bridge. Please consider this an early version. @motus fail tests have been ported to Org.Apache.REEF.Bridge.Core.Tests and all run successfully. However, this PR needs polishing and is out now so that @singlis can start getting familiar with the design and implementation. Others (@markusweimer @motus @rogancarr) should only view this PR out of curiosity until @singlis is satisfied.
Whoever merges this should fix the title of the commit :)
Well I believe @tcondie can still fix it in his branch with `git commit --amend` or something, and edit the title (and the description) on github
@markusweimer @motus It was a challenging rebase :) I will revise the comments.

Hi @motus,
I've made the change so that MetricTracker's field Records will be null if the metric does not keep history, which simplifies the code somewhat. I kept the KeeupUpdateHistory field in the tracker because it is needed when the driver receives new metric data to decide whether to append or swap out the records.

Regarding ValueUntyped and non-generic IMetric, this is to enable all implementations of IMetric to be stored in the same collection. If IMetric took a generic parameter, then MetricTracker would also need to be templatized, and then MetricsData wouldn't be able to store all the trackers of different types in a single dict. To make up for it, EvaluatorMetrics and DriverMetrics enforces a typed implementation in CreateAndRegister. Hope this makes it clearer.
There is a circular dependency in the project files. `Org.Apache.REEF.Bridge.Core` and `Org.Apache.REEF.Bridge.Core.Driver` depend on each other.

Hi @mandyshieh, I am still trying to understand the logic, but I have a feeling that we can be more type safe in many places. I've played with the code a bit, and pushed some of my changes to my private branch. Please check it out:

https://github.com/apache/reef/compare/d4d84afb5a86d8cb3df0770763a30a2398ea2f9a...motus:REEF-1732?expand=1

There are still a few things that I cannot figure out (e.g. how to get rid of the redundant type parameter in `IDriverMetrics.CreateAndRegisterMetric()`, so please take a look and let me know what you think!

Thank you!
@motus and @markusweimer : This pull request has been reviewed and refined by Tyler and Chenxi. Please review it and merge. Thanks!

Hi @motus,
The changes you've requested have been pushed. In addition to cleaning up unused directives, long lines, etc., there are two main changes:
1. Took out the int ChangesSinceLastSink variable. Instead, the sink checks thresholds by directly counting from the cache of records. That way, there is no chance that a thread might interrupt during updates causing inconsistencies between records and changes.
2. The metric object itself is not reconstructed once records have been passed to the Driver Side, since it is never used.
Hope this addresses your concerns! Let me know what you think.
All comments addressed and ready to go! :D

@motus Thank you for your review! 

@singlis I know you had a look already. Did you have any further suggestions?

@tcondie Thank you for these changes! Is there a list of JIRAs that is tracking any remaining work that needs to be done? Does the new bridge have the same parity with the old bridge? Can the IMRU be switched over to use the new bridge?

The only thing that I decided not to support is submitting a service via an active context. Services are supported via allocated evaluators, and hence, I did not see the need for them to be supported via an active context. 

Other than that, the new bridge is on feature parity with the old, and applications/libraries (e.g., IMRU) can be ported over.
hey folks, can we please move this forward?

Hi Tyson,

I am working on it now! Will post a few minor comments soon and start
testing it in yarn. I'll let you know by tomorrow!

Also, @tcondie how do we build the .NET part on Linux now? is it part of the maven build or do we have to run some dotnet build tool after (or instead of) it?

Building via dotnet command line is not integrated with the maven build. Here's how you'd do it for the HelloREEF project that uses the new bridge:
```
 dotnet publish -f netcoreapp2.0 -r linux-x64 --self-contained true Org.Apache.REEF.Bridge.Core.HelloREEF.csproj
```
This can be executed on linux e.g., I do it via WSL.

FYI - I upgraded my VS to 15.8.2 and was able to build successfully (with the latest change of removing global.json).

@tcondie  - There ~15 tests that are failing on the appveyor build. We usually have some intermittent tests that fail, but some them don't look to be in the usual intermittent group (like Azure Batch). Do these pass for you locally?

@singlis Thanks Scott for pointing out the test failures. I have address them by either revising the test or removing it due to the test no longer making sense. More specifically, REEF.NET assumed that if a task failed then the Evaluator should crash. This, however, does not happen on the Java side. In earlier conversations, I pointed out this semantic mismatch, and decided to correct it in the new bridge. As such, tests on the old bridge that assumed the incorrect semantics have been either removed or revised to match the correct semantics. 

At this point, I believe tests that fail either do so in main or pass on my location machine: one instance of this is:
```
Org.Apache.REEF.Tests.Functional.IMRU.TestFailMapperEvaluatorsOnInit.TestFailedMapperOnLocalRuntime [FAIL]
```
Which passes on my local machine but seems to fail on AppVeyor because in can't read the log:
```
Cannot read from log file C:\projects\reef\lang\cs\bin\.netcore\Release\Org.Apache.REEF.Tests\net461\REEF_LOCAL_RUNTIME7253ce0e\reef-BroadcastReduceDriver-20180907140304298\driver\driver.stdout
```

Moving forward, it is my understanding that all of these tests will go away when the new bridge is in place, which is why I ported @motus  tests over to the new bridge. That will resolve the issue with the tests that fail in main.

Thank you again for your extremely helpful feedback!

There is no way to build REEF.NET completely on Linux at this moment - many `.csproj` files are Windows-only, and it would take another PR to port the .NET build system to Linux/dotnet. I am thinking about merging this PR into master as is, and then work on Linux port, YARN runtime, deprecation of the old bridge etc in separate PRs. @markusweimer, WDYT?

@tcondie do you have any ideas what's going on there and how we can fix that in our build?

I got a little ahead of what happened. So Tyson feel free to correct. Here is what I see that is happening. The JAR project (Org.Apache.REEF.JAR) that builds the java side of REEF is not listed as a dependency for Bridge.Core. Therefore we do not build jar files for the project. The JAR project not only builds the Java side, but also copies the jar files to be bundled into a REEF assembly. 

With these changes, you are bundling the jar file in Org.Apache.Bridge.Core.Grpc.csproj file. I believe this is failing silently if jar files do not exist as we grabbing with a glob of *.jar.

As a result Sergiy tried to build out the JAR project manually on Linux and thats when he hit the issues with mvn.cmd and protoc.exe. As quick fix to see if this would work, he renamed the commands to be linux specific and this uncovered the next issue, which is that msbuild tries to build the JAR project -- not dotnet. I believe the JAR csproj needs to be converted to work as a Rosyln task in order to get this working in order to build with dotnet.

Spot on @singlis 

I'll switch it over to a use Rosyln tasks, hopefully without too much effort, then make it a netstandard2.0 library. I'm on a short vacation now, so let me do this on Tuesday.

Thanks guys (@motus and @singlis) for your help! It's good to get a solid bridge committed.

@markusweimer, the build failure is not introduced by these new changes. 

Is there anything else I can do before commit?

No, but I am trying to build & test before merge. It will take me a bit to do that
Tests pass on my side. I will merge.

@motus @singlis So here is the deal. I can not take a direct dependency on Org.Apache.REEF.Bridge.JAR because there is not .dll file associated with that project. 

Spoke to @singlis some time ago, and we concluded that it should be rolled into one of the existing bridge projects e.g., Org.Apache.REEF.Bridge.Core.Common. However, the old bridge depends on this being a separate project.

So why did it work before. Well it works for msbuild because of the .sln compile order preferences, which (it would seem) dotnet does not support. 

I suggest this be put in as a separate Jira once this PR goes in, which at this point I see no reason to hold off on. Thoughts?

That sounds good to me as I see the main focus of this PR is to add the .net core bridge. There is follow-up that can be tracked via JIRAs. Since this implementation of the bridge sits side-by-side with the other bridge, committing this change should not cause any blocking scenarios (runtime or build).

I agree as well. We can scope this change to make it so that REEF.NET is built on Windows, but runs on Linux. Building on Linux can be a goal of another JIRA, preferably done after we remove the old bridge.
Perhaps @singlis can do the honors if there are no further comments?
Sounds great! @singlis let's do this tomorrow

We will need a JIRA(s) to track migrating IMRU to move to the new bridge as well as deprecating the old bridge.

@tcondie  @markusweimer  sorry for the delay, I currently don't have permissions to merge and I am working to resolve this. I am going to keep on eye on this through the day to see if it resolves.

Thanks for the feedback @markusweimer. I have posted an update. Although there is one issue that bothers me with lists which is no code seems to serialize a list of classes, it looks to always be a string.

Is serializing out a list of classes that can be injected supposed to work? 

I started to make changes to this to see what it would take. First I had to modify this signature:
```
ICsConfigurationBuilder BindList<U, V, T>(GenericType<U> iface, IList<GenericType<V>> impl)
```
to
```
ICsConfigurationBuilder BindList<U, V, T>(GenericType<U> iface, IList<V> impl)
```
Then I added a test similar to what is done with Sets:

```
ICsConfigurationBuilder cb = TangFactory.GetTang().NewConfigurationBuilder();
var t = new System.Collections.Generic.List<Integer1>();
t.Add(new Integer1(2));
t.Add(new Integer1(3));
cb.BindList<ListOfClasses, Integer1, INumber>(GenericType<ListOfClasses>.Class, t)

IInjector i = TangFactory.GetTang().NewInjector(cb.Build());
IList<INumber> actual = i.GetInstance<PoolList>().Numbers;
```

The error is on the last line when we try to call GetInstance to construct the object. It looks like it has to do with resolving the parameters (2,3) to pass to the class on construction. Note PoolList is a class that has an inject constructor. It takes in IList<INumber> as the parameter, it has a property called Numbers that returns an IList of INumbers:
```
            [Inject]
            private PoolList([Parameter(typeof(ListOfClasses))] IList<INumber> numbers)
```

> Is serializing out a list of classes that can be injected supposed to work?

I don't think so. Tang enforces singleton semantics for objects to be instantiated by it. And in a List, one can refer to the same type multiple times, without giving it a name as in `NamedParameter`. Hence, I believe it is expected behavior for this to only ever work with Sets.
Sorry for late response. I will have a quick look today.
@jwang98052, would you please review when you get the chance?
@markusweimer, when you get the chance, can you take a look at this change?
Ready for the second round!

Hi, @motus .
Could you review this please?
Thank you for review and mergeing, @motus .

>
> Few very minor comments for today. Check for naming conventions and make
>> sure you use {0}-style string interpolation in logging instead of string
>> concatenation or $"". (Note that for exceptions it's the other way
>> around)
>
> Can you please explain to me the intuition behind this?
>

Sure! In case of explicit string concatenation or $"..." - style
interpolation, the entire string is evaluated *before* the method
invocation. This is exactly what we need for exceptions and most of other
methods and constructors as well.

For logging, the situation is different, as we don't know if the string
will be used at all. If the log level is higher than the priority of the
current log message, the logging call is basically a no-op, and the string
parameter will be ignored. That is, if we build a string *before* the
logging call, it can be a big waste, especially if the log message is long
and expensive to construct. This is why for logging we want to perform
string interpolation *inside* the logging method, so the logger can do it
only when it knows for sure that we need to log that string. Sometimes we
even wrap the logging call into Logger.IsLoggable() check, if interpolation
at the logger level is not possible.

Internal logging string interpolation uses {0}-style placeholders, hence
the rule: use {0} style for logging, $"..." for everything else.

Hope that helps! :)

Cheers,
Sergiy.

> Here's another round of comments. Also, please remove the trailing spaces that popped up in the last commit [55aedfa](https://github.com/apache/reef/commit/55aedfaf2549da8d52b0843a3961f830b788fd95)

Sorry @motus which trailing spaces are you referring to?

Let me take track of the major changes I will have to do (once you are done with the "syntactic" pass). I will update this list as we agree on the changes.
* remove the id - 1, +1 thing. Move everything to 0-indexed;
* configurations are immutable: fix the methods passing `ref` configurations
* change custom retry logic with `Microsoft.Practices.EnterpriseLibrary.TransientFaultHandling`
* discuss on incompatibility between `DefaultFailureStates` and `IFailureState`. Should we remove `enum` or remove `IFailureState`?

Code snippet of **<org.objectweb.asm.ClassReader: void accept(org.objectweb.asm.ClassVisitor,org.objectweb.asm.Attribute[],int)>** in **org.ow2.asm:asm:jar:4.2**:
![attribute4 2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/46306510/53679454-d9d21500-3d07-11e9-9b22-580a29555371.png)


Code snippet of **<org.objectweb.asm.ClassReader: void accept(org.objectweb.asm.ClassVisitor,org.objectweb.asm.Attribute[],int)>** in **org.ow2.asm:asm:jar:5.0.3**:
![attribute5 0 3](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/46306510/53679465-f66e4d00-3d07-11e9-8878-416114ee7dd6.png)


The above method  included in newer version deals with more cases, which changes the control flows and data flows. So being forced to use older version **org.ow2.asm:asm:jar:4.2** may lead to inconsisitent semantic behaviors.

The issue description is available in Jira: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-2056?filter=-2

Thanks for your attention.
@johnyangk Could you help me review this issue? Thank you very much!

I mean, I can probably change the serialization/deserialization of messages to use protobuff, but to completely use protobuff end to end I will have to go and change the network service (which is not my code) and this may require some indefinite amount of time. Do you think it is ok if I only try protobuff for my messages?

messages that you create and serialize on your own, not all the Wake stuff.
I am on vacation toll Wednesday - let's discuss it next week when I am back!

Thank you,
Sergiy.

Thanks for the update, @Rajpratik71! While you are at it, can we also add a few more options, just in case the parent image has some unexpected defaults? Also, I would probably move all options after the `install` clause and use extended versions for each (as in, `--yes` instead of `-y`). That is, each call will look like
```bash
apt-get install --yes --no-upgrade --no-install-recommends --no-install-suggests ...
```
Can you please do that?

Also, most importantly -- can you also open a corresponding JIRA issue for your PR at https://issues.apache.org/jira/projects/REEF and format your commit message according to our guidelines at https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/REEF/Commit+Messages

Thank you!
